content: SECTION 1. NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SPACE. The Administrator will establish a National Academy of Space to train individuals for space-related roles. The Academy will offer science, math, and engineering degrees at selected universities with a uniform curriculum. A Board will be appointed to oversee the Academy's operations. The National Academy of Space, overseen by a Board, will develop exams for students, set curriculum criteria for Member Institutes, place scholarship recipients at Member Institutes, and administer scholarship awards. The Board will select 6-10 State universities with strong programs in science, math, and engineering as Member Institutes of the Academy. These universities must provide housing, board, and the Academy's curriculum for scholarship winners. The Board annually certifies top scorers in each district and awards scholarships to students willing to commit to service at the Academy. Scholarships are available for undergraduate study, with additional scholarships awarded for each academic year. The Space Corps scholarships are awarded for undergraduate study, with the possibility of receiving up to 3 additional awards. Scholarship proceeds are disbursed to the students' enrolled institutions. Eligibility requires U.S. citizenship or lawful permanent residence and majoring in physical, life, or computer sciences. Undergraduate students majoring in physical, life, or computer sciences, mathematics, or engineering at an institution of higher education are eligible for awards under this section. To receive continuation awards, students must maintain high academic achievement and continue to major in one of the specified fields. The Administrator may waive full-time attendance requirements in unusual circumstances and suspend scholarship eligibility if a student fails to meet requirements. The Administrator can reinstate eligibility under certain circumstances. The scholarship recipient may be reinstated for personal reasons like pregnancy or family responsibilities. The scholarship covers full tuition and fees, with adjustments if funds are insufficient. Recipients must agree to complete 4 years of service. The scholarship recipient must agree to complete 4 years of service in a space-related capacity, postgraduate education in science or engineering, or a combination of both. Failure to fulfill the service obligation results in a repayment obligation. Failure to complete the service obligation results in repayment of total awards received plus interest within 1 year. The Administrator may waive or suspend obligations or payments in certain cases. Authorization of Appropriations: $9,000,000 for fiscal year 1996, $4,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1997 to 2000, to establish a permanent headquarters for the Academy. Repayment of awards plus interest required for failure to complete service obligation, with waivers available in certain cases. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The term "Administrator" refers to the head of NASA, "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965, and "State" includes all 50 states, territories, and possessions represented in Congress.
